_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DRISCOLL SALINAS
                                                           EXECUTIVE SUMMARY  

In response to the Monterey County Environmental Health Services Department directive, and as stipulated in sections 25531 to 25543.3 of the Health and Safety code, this Risk Management Plan (RMP), as outlined in the CalARP (California Accidental Release Prevention Program) Emergency Regulations, has been developed for the Driscoll Strawberry Associates Inc. strawberry cooling and shipping facility in Salinas, California.   The purpose of this RMP is to:

  Increase the protection of public health and the environment by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling an acutely hazardous material (AHM).

  Assist Driscoll Strawberry Assoc. Inc. and the local governmental agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling an AHM.

This document addresses the existing AHM system used for the produce refrigeration process at the Driscoll Strawberry Assoc. Inc. facility.  The AHM used at the facility and for the focus of this study is anhydrous ammonia.  The devices that circulate and store the ammonia will be the subject of investigation throughout this RMP document.

 Driscoll Strawberry Assoc. Inc. is located within the city limits of Salinas, California, in a predominately business/industrial area, and is a produce pre-cooling, cold storage, and shipping facility.   The facility was first constructed on this site in 1984 and has been in continuous seasonal operation since that time.   Anhydrous ammonia is used as the closed loop system refrigerant for the 29,300 sq ft cold storage warehouse and pre-cooling equipment in an amount of approximately 5000 lbs., and is the only acutely hazardous chemical used on the site.   The balance of the facility located on the approximate 5 acre paved site consists of a 15,000 sq ft storage warehouse.   
The risks to the community from this facility would come fr

om an incident in which the ammonia normally contained within the plant refrigeration system was allowed to escape into the atmosphere.   In the worst-case scenario the toxic end point is located off the property within the community.  The alternate release scenario was selected as the most likely event that could have a toxic endpoint located off of the subject property.   Events which were considered possible and able to cause a release of ammonia for the purposes of the Hazard Review were:  equipment failure, operator error, design deficiency, vehicular accident, and acts of sabotage/vandalism, fire and earthquake.   It is expected that other specific events would have similar results as those listed above.   Direct contact with the released ammonia vapor by people inside the toxic endpoint is the main area of concern.
       The worst-case release scenario considered was as required, specifically being the release of 100% of the ammonia contained within the largest vessel over a 10-minute period.   The analytical results of this scenario show a distance to the toxic endpoint of approximately .83 miles, which includes mainly industrial development, agricultural land, and a smaller amount of residential area.   The alternative release scenario was chosen as the most likely event involving the release of 300 lbs. of ammonia over a 30-minute period from a leaking valve or cracked pipe.   The distance to the toxic endpoint would be less than .1 miles in this case.   Both scenarios can result in off-site impacts.


Administrative controls and policies:   to be used in the event of a release are contained in the existing " Business Response Plans and Procedures - 2003".   The major topics covered by this document are:
               1.  Emergency Response Personnel
               2.  Hazard Assessment
               3. Notification Procedures
               4. Utility Shut-Off Information
               5. Evacuation Plan and Procedures
               6. Mitigation and

Abatement Steps
               7. Employee Training
               8. Administration
               9. Site Plan,  Facility Layout

Prevention of Accidental Ammonia Releases:   is addressed by the following:
               1.   System design and construction
               2.   Administrative controls
               3.   Off-hours security service

      Risk reduction steps have been and are continuing to be implemented by Driscoll       Strawberry Assoc. Inc., to: minimize the possibility of an accidental release of ammonia, and in the event of an accidental release, to minimize the effects upon the community.   The essential risk reduction steps now in effect at this facility are:
               1.   Regular daily equipment observations		
               2.   Maintaining equipment and keeping maintenance records
               3.   Maintaining records of previous releases/causes           
               4.   Proper training of operators
               5.   Mechanical and electrical system controls automatically maintain the correct system
                     temperatures and pressures, and provide safety shut-down and pressure relief in the event 
                     that the system operates out of its design limits.
               6.   Pressure vessels are equipped with high level alarm switches.
               7.   All equipment and system components are designed for ammonia service
               8.  The system appears to have been designed and installed in accordance with applicable    
                    Federal, State and local codes.


Five Year Accident History:
This facility has not experienced an ammonia release within the last five years    which resulted in the evacuation and/or sheltering in place of neighboring residents and/or properties.




Emergency Response Program:
               This facility currently operates under an  Emergency Response Plan which:
                        a.  Identifies the Emergency Coordinator and Emergency Contacts

b.  Details the Emergency Notification Procedures
                        c.  Contains procedures for hazardous material incidents
                        d.  Details reporting procedures
                        e.  Contains the evacuation plan
                        f.   Shows the locations of all acutely hazardous materials on-site
                        g.  Shows the locations of emergency response and mitigation equipment on site
                        h.  See Appendix.

Utility System:
This facility is connected to PG&E and is subject to possible power failures.  The failure of a refrigeration system to operate during a power outage poses no risk of an ammonia release since loss of power simply stops the flow of ammonia within the system.   In the event of a post-earthquake fire at the site, water for firefighting and/or ammonia dilution is drawn from the city water system.  The post-earthquake functionality of the water system thus depends on the vulnerability of PG&E and the water system to earthquake induced failure, which is unknown.

Recommended plant improvements to increase safety.      
             1.   Provide pipe labeling as per UMC and ANSI/ASHRAE standards.
             2.   Replace PRV's on 5 year cycles as per code
             3.   Install proper seismic restraints on ammonia piping and equipment 
             4.   Install diffusion tank w/ PRV manifold
             5.   Install solenoid controlled king valve(s)
             6.   Connect existing refrigeration equipment alarm system to the auto-dialer
